Title: Carlos

Country: France, Germany
USA release:
Released in Spain: 15/04/2011

Studio: Alta Films

Screenplay: Olivier Assayas, Dan Franck
Cast: Edgar Ramirez, Alexander Scheer, Nora Von Waldstatt, Ahmad Kaabour, Christoph Bach, Rodney El-Haddad, Julia Hummer, Rami Farah, Zeid Hamdan, Talal El-Jurdi, Fadi Abi Samra


Synopsis:
Tells the story of Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, who for two decades was one of the world's most wanted terrorists. Between 1974, in London, where he tried to assassinate a Jewish businessman, and 1994, he was arrested in Khartoum, he lived several lives under various pseudonyms to his own way through the complexities of international politics at the time.

Who was Charles? How he managed to hold together their different personalities? Who was before engaging in body and soul in an endless struggle? CARLOS is built on these questions.

Authentic legendary, Carlos starred in the history of international terrorism from the 1970 and 1980, from pro-Palestinian activism to the Japanese Red Army. Figure at the same time the extreme left and opportunistic mercenary hired by the secret services of powers in the Middle East, he formed his own organization, installed across the Iron Curtain and was active during the last years of the Cold War.

The film is the story of a revolutionary internationalist, manipulator and manipulated, led by the current of contemporary history, to be continued to the end of the road, relegated in Sudan, where Islamic dictatorship, after having protected a time, surrendered to the French police. Contradictory character, so violent as the time it embodies, Carlos is also an enigma, at least in part, we intend to decipher.

CARLOS The film was based upon a great deal of historical documentation and journalism. However, in the life of Carlos there are significant areas of shadow, controversial, and this film is primarily a fiction that traces two decades of the life of one of the most famous terrorist of our time.
